keyTakeAways: A steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon broke, resulting in a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable failed to meet specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular's operator, and was not certified to carry passengers.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and brakes.
Maintenance tasks were marked as completed even when not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as compliant.
The preliminary report is not conclusive, and a final report is expected to be released next year.
Eyewitnesses described the descent as chaotic and uncontrollable, with one man, Bruno, reporting the car behaving like a toy and producing a loud bang and brown smoke.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A fatal crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped mid-journey. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet safety specifications set by the operator, CARRIS, and that maintenance records were falsified, with tasks marked as completed even when not performed. Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the descent as chaotic and terrifying. While the interim report highlights serious failures in cable integrity, maintenance practices, and braking systems, it is noted that the findings are preliminary and a final report is expected next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
